metadata.synopsis: After the SCE debrief, Minthara sits on Ketheric's throne and dreams of what lies ahead.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Debug Book -> Set quest flags -> Act 2 -> SCE - Epilogue -> Set up evil path -> Start the debrief.

112.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
112.text: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
112.context: CinematicNodeContext: seated on Ketheric's throne in a casual pose, looking very pleased with herself

123.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
123.text: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.

267.speaker: Player
267.text: I hoped you would - we make a good team.

287.speaker: Player
287.text: Excellent - I could have used your help against Ketheric. He was a formidable foe.

288.speaker: Player
288.text: Shouldn't you be skulking off back to the Underdark?

182.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
182.text: I do not have a home there anymore - my own siblings would slay me.

16.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
16.text: I go where my enemies are, and they are not here in the shadows. They are in Baldur's Gate.

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: And they will pose a greater threat than Ketheric.

188.speaker: Player
188.text: No - you're staying here in the shadows.

155.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
155.text: We should not tarry in this charnel house long.
155.context: CinematicNodeContext: seated on Ketheric's throne in a casual pose, looking very pleased with herself

236.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
236.text: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
236.context: CinematicNodeContext: seated on Ketheric's throne in a casual pose, looking very pleased with herself

269.speaker: Player
269.text: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
269.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on

85.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
85.text: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.

248.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
248.text: Yes - although I wish we had collaborated on the killing itself.

219.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
219.text: But I will satisfy my war-lust soon, for there are greater challenges than Ketheric ahead of us.

184.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
184.text: We make an acceptable team. But there are greater challenges than Ketheric ahead of us.

153.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
153.text: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Ketheric was a dead man long before we arrived - a servant of Myrkul, Lord of Bones.
108.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on

33.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
33.text: Indeed. And now we know that he was not acting alone.

86.speaker: Player
86.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on

12.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
12.text: Power always has. But I shall not get too comfortable here.
12.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on

175.text: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
175.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on

282.text: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.

284.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
284.text: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.

130.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
130.text: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.

187.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
187.text: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.

117.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
117.text: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.

238.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
238.text: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.

239.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
239.text: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.

293.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
293.text: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: First Myrkul, now Bhaal - I feel like we're in over our heads.

256.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
256.text: If the gods stand in our way, we will tear them down. Nothing will deny me my vengeance on Orin.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.

97.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
97.text: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.

196.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
196.text: He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.

198.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
198.text: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: What do you remember of your indoctrination?

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.

32.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
32.text: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.

296.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
296.text: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.

273.speaker: Player
273.text: You committed atrocities in the name of those lies.

177.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
177.text: And for that I am sorry. I will commit all future atrocities for my own gain - and yours, should we stand together.

220.speaker: Player
220.text: What can you tell me about Orin?

224.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
224.text: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.

27.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
27.text: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.

96.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
96.text: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.

29.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
29.text: Now I know that those memories are lies.

87.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
87.text: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.

140.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
140.text: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.

240.speaker: Player
240.text: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.

252.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
252.text: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.

47.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
47.text: I expected you would be, but know this...

292.speaker: Player
292.text: You make it sound so simple.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: Tempting, but eradicating the brain may be wiser, to put an end to this madness.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: What I propose is nigh on impossible, but if anyone can succeed, it is us. We have the Prism, and we have the courage to slay gods.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.

76.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
76.text: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.

169.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
169.text: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?

265.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
265.text: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: What would we do with that power?

88.speaker: Player
88.text: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.

216.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
216.text: We may fail, but we must try.

50.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
50.text: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

107.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
107.text: Patience. If we do not prepare, Baldur's Gate will be our tomb.

206.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
206.text: But if we are wise, it will be our dominion.

289.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
289.text: First we take the Netherstones, then the brain, then the world.

208.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
208.text: And then we will need no gods. We will be their equal. We will be Absolute.

69.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
69.text: We have a purpose and a bond. By my oath, I will fight with you while that purpose holds.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.

217.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
217.text: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.

122.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
122.text: There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.

48.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
48.text: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.

173.speaker: Player
173.text: You may be right. I'll keep an open mind.

109.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
109.text: That is all I ask. And remember, I know when your mind is closed.

94.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
94.text: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
94.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

167.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
167.text: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
167.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

186.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
186.text: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
186.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

280.speaker: Player
280.text: Does it matter? They were nobody.
280.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

247.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
247.text: I don't care about them, I care about you.

231.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
231.text: So I ask again - why kill the inhabitants of the Grove?

61.speaker: Player
61.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

150.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
150.text: I'm flattered. Will you be bringing dead rats and birds to my tent now that we share a camp?

146.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
146.text: I jest, but it is as good a reason as any. I have done much more foolish things to win the respect of far inferior people.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: I was hoping to earn your trust so that I could learn more about the tadpoles.
260.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

0.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
0.text: A wise ploy, and it was successful, to an extent. We did not find a cure, but we found our purpose.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: I ask myself the same question, and I don't have an answer.
251.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.
65.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

179.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
179.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

290.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
290.text: Those who kill without motive cannot be trusted. I would not like to wake with your knife at my throat, and never understand the reason why.
290.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

1.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
1.text: Perhaps in time, I can help direct your violence. Until then, I will watch my back.
1.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

137.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
137.text: There's no space for me. I suggest you make one.
137.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

246.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
246.text: Your party is full. Did you think I would not notice?
246.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: All right. Meet me at camp.
111.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: You can take Astarion's place - he'll head back to camp.
253.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

106.speaker: Narrator
106.text: *Your companion is otherwise engaged. You'll need to dismiss them at a more convenient moment.*
106.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

148.speaker: Narrator
148.text: *Your companion is otherwise engaged. You'll need to dismiss them at a more convenient moment.*

73.speaker: Player
73.text: If I must. Do try to keep them safe - they're a little useless without me.
73.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

37.speaker: Astarion
37.text: This is my replacement? Good luck to you both.
37.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: Gale could do with a rest.
84.context: NodeContext: Well. I know when I'm not wanted. - not shitty, just gentle faux haughtiness

213.speaker: Narrator
213.text: I'll get little rest given the stack of unread books waiting for me - but I'll try.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: I'll get little rest given the stack of unread books waiting for me - but I'll try.

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: Keeping your greatest weapon in reserve, eh? An excellent strategy.

163.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
163.text: As you like. Let us go forth and conquer. Or something to that effect.

152.speaker: Player
152.context: NodeContext: Well. I know when I'm not wanted. - not shitty, just gentle faux haughtiness

78.speaker: Narrator
78.context: NodeContext: Well. I know when I'm not wanted. - not shitty, just gentle faux haughtiness

181.speaker: Player
181.context: NodeContext: Well. I know when I'm not wanted. - not shitty, just gentle faux haughtiness

57.speaker: Jaheira
57.text: Well. I know when I'm not wanted.
57.context: NodeContext: Well. I know when I'm not wanted. - not shitty, just gentle faux haughtiness

91.speaker: Player
91.context: NodeContext: A bit immature bad attitude. Player has told her to swap with someone else who wants to join the party.

20.speaker: Narrator
20.text: Aw! Why me?! Guess I'll just sit on my thumb in camp then.
20.context: NodeContext: A bit immature bad attitude. Player has told her to swap with someone else who wants to join the party.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: Aw! Why me?! Guess I'll just sit on my thumb in camp then.
158.context: NodeContext: A bit immature bad attitude. Player has told her to swap with someone else who wants to join the party.

203.speaker: Karlach
203.context: NodeContext: A bit immature bad attitude. Player has told her to swap with someone else who wants to join the party.

258.speaker: Narrator
258.text: Fine. I shall wait in our camp.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Fine. I shall wait in our camp.

13.speaker: Shadowheart
13.text: If you insist. Don't have all the fun without me.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: You can trade places with Wyll.

281.speaker: Narrator
281.text: Off I go. You'll know where to find me!

245.speaker: Player
245.text: Off I go. You'll know where to find me!

42.speaker: Wyll
42.text: All right. I know a shortcut.

60.speaker: Narrator
60.text: I shall remain at camp for now.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: I shall remain at camp for now.

207.speaker: Halsin
207.text: I shall be waiting. Come find me when you need me.

264.speaker: Narrator
264.text: Who would I be to question your wisdom?

59.speaker: Player
59.text: Who would I be to question your wisdom?

297.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
297.text: I will wait in camp. Patiently, even.

286.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
286.text: Now. I am ready to leave this damned place whenever you give the word. The city awaits.

190.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
190.text: Me too, but I am keen to find joy in the consequences of the killing as well as in the act itself.

168.speaker: Player
168.text: A violent urge drives me. I wasn't in control of my actions.

26.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
26.text: But you had the Prism, did you not? So the Absolute was not the cause.

2.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
2.text: Are you in control of your actions now?

102.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
102.text: Good. Whatever afflicted you, we can leave it in the past, like the corpses in the Grove.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: Good. Whatever afflicted you, we can leave it in the past, like the corpses in the Grove.

195.text: I like the deliberate nature of the lie even less than the disorder of your actions.

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: I like the deliberate nature of the lie even less than the disorder of your actions.

145.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
145.text: That will do. For now. We should speak more of whatever afflicts you, but there will be time for that.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: No. An omnipresent authority figure controls all of my actions.

226.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
226.text: Then you are no different than I once was.

285.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
285.text: We can travel together, but there can be no trust between us.

142.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
142.text: You chose to incapacitate me rather than killing me when you eradicated my minions. Why?

45.speaker: Player
45.text: I thought that if I could free you from the Absolute's control, you might be a worthy ally.

249.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
249.text: So might any other True Soul, and yet Gut and Ragzlin do not stand with us, under your protection.

291.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
291.text: Sparing an enemy's life is a great risk. Even though I owe my life to the part of you that showed me mercy, it concerns me.

116.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
116.text: If Ketheric had ordered me to slay you to prove my worth, I would have. Or died trying.

125.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
125.text: I should not lose myself in these thoughts of what might have been. I live, and I am grateful.

235.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
235.text: I do have one more question though, before we continue.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: Most people would be grateful to live, not suspicious of their saviour.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: You were simply too stubborn to die.

259.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
259.text: You describe me well, but you deceive nonetheless. You chose to spare me, I am sure of it.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: You deserve a chance to return to Lolth's side. I could not let you die worshipping a false god.

244.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
244.text: No god commands me now. But out of respect for what you have done for me, for my salvation, I shall follow you whatever your beliefs.

257.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
257.text: Why come to Moonrise, where the cult's power is strongest? Why not walk away?

135.speaker: Player
135.text: Coming here was my best chance to learn more about the tadpole. Possibly even cure it.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I want revenge on those who did this to me.

100.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
100.text: Good. That is as it should be.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: The cult are a threat to the world. I aim to eradicate them.

194.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
194.text: Drought, famine and warfare are threats to the world as well. Do you intend to eradicate them?

118.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
118.text: The cult are a threat to you. That is what matters.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: Walking away wouldn't have helped. While the tadpole lives, I can't be free.

255.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
255.text: True. But do not lose yourself to despair and fatalism. They tried to make victims of us, but we can take this opportunity to become gods.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: I was just looking for more people to kill.

141.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
141.text: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.

191.speaker: Player
191.text: If you go to Baldur's Gate, you're going alone.

211.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
211.text: Without you - without the Prism - I cannot risk going to the city. The Absolute would take my mind again.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: Good. The world will be safe from your mad ambitions.

36.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
36.text: My time will come. With or without you.

39.speaker: Player
39.text: You can stay with me if you swear to follow my lead.

156.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
156.text: Fine. All I ask of you is that you keep an open mind.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.

278.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
278.text: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.

162.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
162.text: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: Is vengeance the limit of your ambitions?

121.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
121.text: There is no limit to my ambitions. I will enjoy killing Orin, but unlike her, I do not kill for pleasure alone. I kill to gain advantage.

234.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
234.text: And we have the chance to seize the greatest advantage of all. Surely you see it?

38.speaker: Player
38.text: There was another with Ketheric - Gortash. Do you know anything about him?

105.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
105.text: Only that he serves Bane, which could make him a petty lordling, or a despot capable of bending the world to his will.

144.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
144.text: That he has enslaved illithids to fulfil his ambitions strongly suggests he is the latter.

51.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
51.text: The Harper may know more - her precious Baldur's Gate was the soil that nourished his growth.
